Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: An office function with colleagues of all genders is scheduled this afternoon.
Story: I stood in front of my closet, my mother’s voice echoing from the kitchen, “Wear the new shirt I bought for you, beta. It’s a family tradition to dress up for Eid, remember?” The shirt was bright, short-sleeved, and paired with fitted trousers—exactly the kind of outfit my family expected me to wear for special occasions. They loved seeing me blend in, looking sharp and modern, just like my cousins. But as a Muslim, I felt the weight of another expectation: to dress modestly, especially in mixed company. The office function this afternoon would be full of colleagues, men and women, and I knew the Islamic guidelines—loose clothing, sleeves to the wrist, nothing flashy. My mother peeked in, her eyes hopeful, and I felt the pressure mounting. I wanted to make her proud, to honor our family’s way, but I also wanted to stay true to my faith. My hands trembled as I held the shirt, torn between two worlds, each demanding a different version of me.
